<s> The drawers are loose elephant-legged and elephant-waisted things, and instead of buttoning around the body there is a drawstring to produce the required shrinkage </s>
<s> The jacket is roomy, and one buttons it in front </s>
<s> Pyjamas are hot on a hot night and cold on a cold night--defects which a nightshirt is free from </s>
<s> I tried the pyjamas in order to be in the fashion; but I was obliged to give them up, I couldn't stand them </s>
<s> There was no sufficient change from day-gear to night-gear </s>
<s> I missed the refreshing and luxurious sense, induced by the night-gown, of being undressed, emancipated, set free from restraints and trammels </s>
<s> In place of that, I had the worried, confined, oppressed, suffocated sense of being abed with my clothes on </s>
<s> All through the warm half of the night the coarse surfaces irritated my skin and made it feel baked and feverish, and the dreams which came in the fitful flurries of slumber were such as distress the sleep of the damned, or ought to; and all through the cold other half of the night I could get no time for sleep because I had to employ it all in stealing blankets </s>
<s> But blankets are of no value at such a time; the higher they are piled the more effectively they cork the cold in and keep it from getting out </s>
<s> The result is that your legs are ice, and you know how you will feel by and by when you are buried </s>
<s> In a sane interval I discarded the pyjamas, and led a rational and comfortable life thenceforth </s>
<s> Out in the country in India, the day begins early </s>
<s> One sees a plain, perfectly flat, dust-colored and brick-yardy, stretching limitlessly away on every side in the dim gray light, striped everywhere with hard-beaten narrow paths, the vast flatness broken at wide intervals by bunches of spectral trees that mark where villages are; and along all the paths are slender women and the black forms of lanky naked men moving, to their work, the women with brass water-jars on their heads, the men carrying hoes </s>
<s> The man is not entirely naked; always there is a bit of white rag, a loin-cloth; it amounts to a bandage, and is a white accent on his black person, like the silver band around the middle of a pipe-stem </s>
<s> Sometimes he also wears a fluffy and voluminous white turban, and this adds a second accent </s>
<s> He then answers properly to Miss Gordon Cumming's flash-light picture of him--as a person who is dressed in "a turban and a pocket handkerchief" </s>
<s> All day long one has this monotony of dust-colored dead levels and scattering bunches of trees and mud villages </s>
<s> You soon realize that India is not beautiful; still there is an enchantment about it that is beguiling, and which does not pall </s>
<s> You cannot tell just what it is that makes the spell, perhaps, but you feel it and confess it, nevertheless </s>
<s> Of course, at bottom, you know in a vague way that it is history; it is that that affects you, a haunting sense of the myriads of human lives that have blossomed, and withered, and perished here, repeating and repeating and repeating, century after century, and age after age, the barren and meaningless process; it is this sense that gives to this forlorn, uncomely land power to speak to the spirit and make friends with it; to speak to it with a voice bitter with satire, but eloquent with melancholy </s>
<s> The deserts of Australia and the ice-barrens of Greenland have no speech, for they have no venerable history; with nothing to tell of man and his vanities, his fleeting glories and his miseries, they have nothing wherewith to spiritualize their ugliness and veil it with a charm </s>
<s> There is nothing pretty about an Indian village--a mud one--and I do not remember that we saw any but mud ones on that long flight to Allahabad </s>
<s> It is a little bunch of dirt-colored mud hovels jammed together within a mud wall </s>
<s> As a rule, the rains had beaten down parts of some of the houses, and this gave the village the aspect of a mouldering and hoary ruin </s>
<s> I believe the cattle and the vermin live inside the wall; for I saw cattle coming out and cattle going in; and whenever I saw a villager, he was scratching </s>
<s> This last is only circumstantial evidence, but I think it has value </s>
<s> The village has a battered little temple or two, big enough to hold an idol, and with custom enough to fat-up a priest and keep him comfortable </s>
<s> Where there are Mohammedans there are generally a few sorry tombs outside the village that have a decayed and neglected look </s>
<s> The villages interested me because of things which Major Sleeman says about them in his books--particularly what he says about the division of labor in them </s>
<s> He says that the whole face of India is parceled out into estates of villages; that nine-tenths of the vast population of the land consist of cultivators of the soil; that it is these cultivators who inhabit the villages; that there are certain "established" village servants--mechanics and others who are apparently paid a wage by the village at large, and whose callings remain in certain families and are handed down from father to son, like an estate </s>
<s> He gives a list of these established servants: Priest, blacksmith, carpenter, accountant, washerman, basketmaker, potter, watchman, barber, shoemaker, brazier, confectioner, weaver, dyer, etc In his day witches abounded, and it was not thought good business wisdom for a man to marry his daughter into a family that hadn't a witch in it, for she would need a witch on the premises to protect her children from the evil spells which would certainly be cast upon them by the witches connected with the neighboring families </s>
<s> The office of midwife was hereditary in the family of the basket-maker </s>
<s> It belonged to his wife </s>
<s> She might not be competent, but the office was hers, anyway </s>
<s> Her pay was not high--25 cents for a boy, and half as much for a girl </s>
<s> The girl was not desired, because she would be a disastrous expense by and by </s>
<s> As soon as she should be old enough to begin to wear clothes for propriety's sake, it would be a disgrace to the family if she were not married; and to marry her meant financial ruin; for by custom the father must spend upon feasting and wedding-display everything he had and all he could borrow--in fact, reduce himself to a condition of poverty which he might never more recover from </s>
<s> It was the dread of this prospective ruin which made the killing of girl-babies so prevalent in India in the old days before England laid the iron hand of her prohibitions upon the piteous slaughter </s>
<s> One may judge of how prevalent the custom was, by one of Sleeman's casual electrical remarks, when he speaks of children at play in villages--where girl-voices were never heard </s>
<s> The wedding-display folly is still in full force in India, and by consequence the destruction of girl-babies is still furtively practiced; but not largely, because of the vigilance of the government and the sternness of the penalties it levies </s>
<s> In some parts of India the village keeps in its pay three other servants: an astrologer to tell the villager when he may plant his crop, or make a journey, or marry a wife, or strangle a child, or borrow a dog, or climb a tree, or catch a rat, or swindle a neighbor, without offending the alert and solicitous heavens; and what his dream means, if he has had one and was not bright enough to interpret it himself by the details of his dinner; the two other established servants were the tiger-persuader and the hailstorm discourager </s>
<s> The one kept away the tigers if he could, and collected the wages anyway, and the other kept off the hailstorms, or explained why he failed </s>
<s> He charged the same for explaining a failure that he did for scoring a success </s>
<s> A man is an idiot who can't earn a living in India </s>
<s> Major Sleeman reveals the fact that the trade union and the boycott are antiquities in India </s>
<s> India seems to have originated everything </s>
<s> The "sweeper" belongs to the bottom caste; he is the lowest of the low--all other castes despise him and scorn his office </s>
<s> But that does not trouble him </s>
<s> His caste is a caste, and that is sufficient for him, and so he is proud of it, not ashamed </s>
<s> Sleeman says: "It is perhaps not known to many of my countrymen, even in India, that in every town and city in the country the right of sweeping the houses and streets is a monopoly, and is supported entirely by the pride of castes among the scavengers, who are all of the lowest class </s>
<s> The right of sweeping within a certain range is recognized by the caste to belong to a certain member; and if any other member presumes to sweep within that range, he is excommunicated--no other member will smoke out of his pipe or drink out of his jug; and he can get restored to caste only by a feast to the whole body of sweepers </s>
<s> If any housekeeper within a particular circle happens to offend the sweeper of that range, none of his filth will be removed till he pacifies him, because no other sweeper will dare to touch it; and the people of a town are often more tyrannized over by these people than by any other" </s>
<s> A footnote by Major Sleeman's editor, Mr Vincent Arthur Smith, says that in our day this tyranny of the sweepers' guild is one of the many difficulties which bar the progress of Indian sanitary reform </s>
<s> Think of this: "The sweepers cannot be readily coerced, because no Hindoo or Mussulman would do their work to save his life, nor will he pollute himself by beating the refractory scavenger" </s>
<s> They certainly do seem to have the whip-hand; it would be difficult to imagine a more impregnable position </s>
<s> "The vested rights described in the text are so fully recognized in practice that they are frequently the subject of sale or mortgage" </s>
<s> Just like a milk-route; or like a London crossing-sweepership </s>
<s> It is said that the London crossing-sweeper's right to his crossing is recognized by the rest of the guild; that they protect him in its possession; that certain choice crossings are valuable property, and are saleable at high figures </s>
<s> I have noticed that the man who sweeps in front of the Army and Navy Stores has a wealthy South African aristocratic style about him; and when he is off his guard, he has exactly that look on his face which you always see in the face of a man who is saving up his daughter to marry her to a duke </s>
<s> It appears from Sleeman that in India the occupation of elephant-driver is confined to Mohammedans </s>
<s> I wonder why that is </s>
<s> The water-carrier ('bheestie') is a Mohammedan, but it is said that the reason of that is, that the Hindoo's religion does not allow him to touch the skin of dead kine, and that is what the water-sack is made of; it would defile him </s>
<s> And it doesn't allow him to eat meat; the animal that furnished the meat was murdered, and to take any creature's life is a sin </s>
<s> It is a good and gentle religion, but inconvenient </s>
<s> A great Indian river, at low water, suggests the familiar anatomical picture of a skinned human body, the intricate mesh of interwoven muscles and tendons to stand for water-channels, and the archipelagoes of fat and flesh inclosed by them to stand for the sandbars </s>
<s> Somewhere on this journey we passed such a river, and on a later journey we saw in the Sutlej the duplicate of that river </s>
<s> Curious rivers they are; low shores a dizzy distance apart, with nothing between but an enormous acreage of sand-flats with sluggish little veins of water dribbling around amongst them; Saharas of sand, smallpox-pitted with footprints punctured in belts as straight as the equator clear from the one shore to the other (barring the channel-interruptions)--a dry-shod ferry, you see </s>
<s> Long railway bridges are required for this sort of rivers, and India has them </s>
<s> You approach Allahabad by a very long one </s>
<s> It was now carrying us across the bed of the Jumna, a bed which did not seem to have been slept in for one while or more </s>
<s> It wasn't all river-bed--most of it was overflow ground </s>
<s> Allahabad means "City of God" </s>
<s> I get this from the books </s>
<s> From a printed curiosity--a letter written by one of those brave and confident Hindoo strugglers with the English tongue, called a "babu"--I got a more compressed translation: "Godville" </s>
<s> It is perfectly correct, but that is the most that can be said for it </s>
<s> We arrived in the forenoon, and short-handed; for Satan got left behind somewhere that morning, and did not overtake us until after nightfall </s>
<s> It seemed very peaceful without him </s>
<s> The world seemed asleep and dreaming </s>
<s> I did not see the native town, I think </s>
<s> I do not remember why; for an incident connects it with the Great Mutiny, and that is enough to make any place interesting </s>
<s> But I saw the English part of the city </s>
<s> It is a town of wide avenues and noble distances, and is comely and alluring, and full of suggestions of comfort and leisure, and of the serenity which a good conscience buttressed by a sufficient bank account gives </s>
<s> The bungalows (dwellings) stand well back in the seclusion and privacy of large enclosed compounds (private grounds, as we should say) and in the shade and shelter of trees </s>
<s> Even the photographer and the prosperous merchant ply their industries in the elegant reserve of big compounds, and the citizens drive in there upon their business occasions </s>
<s> And not in cabs--no; in the Indian cities cabs are for the drifting stranger; all the white citizens have private carriages; and each carriage has a flock of white-turbaned black footmen and drivers all over it </s>
<s> The vicinity of a lecture-hall looks like a snowstorm,--and makes the lecturer feel like an opera </s>
<s> India has many names, and they are correctly descriptive </s>
<s> It is the Land of Contradictions, the Land of Subtlety and Superstition, the Land of Wealth and Poverty, the Land of Splendor and Desolation, the Land of Plague and Famine, the Land of the Thug and the Poisoner, and of the Meek and the Patient, the Land of the Suttee, the Land of the Unreinstatable Widow, the Land where All Life is Holy, the Land of Cremation, the Land where the Vulture is a Grave and a Monument, the Land of the Multitudinous Gods; and if signs go for anything, it is the Land of the Private Carriage </s>
<s> In Bombay the forewoman of a millinery shop came to the hotel in her private carriage to take the measure for a gown--not for me, but for another </s>
<s> She had come out to India to make a temporary stay, but was extending it indefinitely; indeed, she was purposing to end her days there </s>
<s> In London, she said, her work had been hard, her hours long; for economy's sake she had had to live in shabby rooms and far away from the shop, watch the pennies, deny herself many of the common comforts of life, restrict herself in effect to its bare necessities, eschew cabs, travel third-class by underground train to and from her work, swallowing coal-smoke and cinders all the way, and sometimes troubled with the society of men and women who were less desirable than the smoke and the cinders </s>
<s> But in Bombay, on almost any kind of wages, she could live in comfort, and keep her carriage, and have six servants in place of the woman-of-all-work she had had in her English home </s>
<s> Later, in Calcutta, I found that the Standard Oil clerks had small one-horse vehicles, and did no walking; and I was told that the clerks of the other large concerns there had the like equipment </s>
<s> But to return to Allahabad </s>
<s> I was up at dawn, the next morning </s>
<s> In India the tourist's servant does not sleep in a room in the hotel, but rolls himself up head and ears in his blanket and stretches himself on the veranda, across the front of his master's door, and spends the night there </s>
<s> I don't believe anybody's servant occupies a room </s>
<s> Apparently, the bungalow servants sleep on the veranda; it is roomy, and goes all around the house </s>
<s> I speak of menservants; I saw none of the other sex </s>
<s> I think there are none, except child-nurses </s>
<s> I was up at dawn, and walked around the veranda, past the rows of sleepers </s>
<s> In front of one door a Hindoo servant was squatting, waiting for his master to call him </s>
<s> He had polished the yellow shoes and placed them by the door, and now he had nothing to do but wait </s>
<s> It was freezing cold, but there he was, as motionless as a sculptured image, and as patient </s>
<s> It troubled me </s>
<s> I wanted to say to him, "Don't crouch there like that and freeze; nobody requires it of you; stir around and get warm" </s>
<s> But I hadn't the words </s>
<s> I thought of saying 'jeldy jow', but I couldn't remember what it meant, so I didn't say it </s>
<s> I knew another phrase, but it wouldn't come to my mind </s>
<s> I moved on, purposing to dismiss him from my thoughts, but his bare legs and bare feet kept him there </s>
<s> They kept drawing me back from the sunny side to a point whence I could see him </s>
<s> At the end of an hour he had not changed his attitude in the least degree </s>
<s> It was a curious and impressive exhibition of meekness and patience, or fortitude or indifference, I did not know which </s>
<s> But it worried me, and it was spoiling my morning </s>
<s> In fact, it spoiled two hours of it quite thoroughly </s>
<s> I quitted this vicinity, then, and left him to punish himself as much as he might want to </s>
<s> But up to that time the man had not changed his attitude a hair </s>
<s> He will always remain with me, I suppose; his figure never grows vague in my memory </s>
<s> Whenever I read of Indian resignation, Indian patience under wrongs, hardships, and misfortunes, he comes before me </s>
<s> He becomes a personification, and stands for India in trouble </s>
<s> And for untold ages India in trouble has been pursued with the very remark which I was going to utter but didn't, because its meaning had slipped me: "Jeldy jow" </s>
<s> ("Come, shove along"!) Why, it was the very thing </s>
<s> In the early brightness we made a long drive out to the Fort </s>
<s> Part of the way was beautiful </s>
<s> It led under stately trees and through groups of native houses and by the usual village well, where the picturesque gangs are always flocking to and fro and laughing and chattering; and this time brawny men were deluging their bronze bodies with the limpid water, and making a refreshing and enticing show of it; enticing, for the sun was already transacting business, firing India up for the day </s>
<s> There was plenty of this early bathing going on, for it was getting toward breakfast time, and with an unpurified body the Hindoo must not eat </s>
<s> Then we struck into the hot plain, and found the roads crowded with pilgrims of both sexes, for one of the great religious fairs of India was being held, just beyond the Fort, at the junction of the sacred rivers, the Ganges and the Jumna </s>
<s> Three sacred rivers, I should have said, for there is a subterranean one </s>
<s> Nobody has seen it, but that doesn't signify </s>
<s> The fact that it is there is enough </s>
<s> These pilgrims had come from all over India; some of them had been months on the way, plodding patiently along in the heat and dust, worn, poor, hungry, but supported and sustained by an unwavering faith and belief; they were supremely happy and content, now; their full and sufficient reward was at hand; they were going to be cleansed from every vestige of sin and corruption by these holy waters which make utterly pure whatsoever thing they touch, even the dead and rotten </s>
<s> It is wonderful, the power of a faith like that, that can make multitudes upon multitudes of the old and weak and the young and frail enter without hesitation or complaint upon such incredible journeys and endure the resultant miseries without repining </s>
<s> It is done in love, or it is done in fear; I do not know which it is </s>
<s> No matter what the impulse is, the act born of it is beyond imagination marvelous to our kind of people, the cold whites </s>
<s> There are choice great natures among us that could exhibit the equivalent of this prodigious self-sacrifice, but the rest of us know that we should not be equal to anything approaching it </s>
<s> Still, we all talk self-sacrifice, and this makes me hope that we are large enough to honor it in the Hindoo </s>
<s> Two millions of natives arrive at this fair every year </s>
<s> How many start, and die on the road, from age and fatigue and disease and scanty nourishment, and how many die on the return, from the same causes, no one knows; but the tale is great, one may say enormous </s>
<s> Every twelfth year is held to be a year of peculiar grace; a greatly augmented volume of pilgrims results then </s>
<s> The twelfth year has held this distinction since the remotest times, it is said </s>
<s> It is said also that there is to be but one more twelfth year--for the Ganges </s>
<s> After that, that holiest of all sacred rivers will cease to be holy, and will be abandoned by the pilgrim for many centuries; how many, the wise men have not stated </s>
<s> At the end of that interval it will become holy again </s>
<s> Meantime, the data will be arranged by those people who have charge of all such matters, the great chief Brahmins </s>
<s> It will be like shutting down a mint </s>
<s> At a first glance it looks most unbrahminically uncommercial, but I am not disturbed, being soothed and tranquilized by their reputation </s>
<s> "Brer fox he lay low," as Uncle Remus says; and at the judicious time he will spring something on the Indian public which will show that he was not financially asleep when he took the Ganges out of the market </s>
<s> Great numbers of the natives along the roads were bringing away holy water from the rivers </s>
<s> They would carry it far and wide in India and sell it </s>
<s> Tavernier, the French traveler (17th century), notes that Ganges water is often given at weddings, "each guest receiving a cup or two, according to the liberality of the host; sometimes 2,000 or 3,000 rupees' worth of it is consumed at a wedding" </s>
<s> The Fort is a huge old structure, and has had a large experience in religions </s>
<s> In its great court stands a monolith which was placed there more than 2,000 years ago to preach (Budhism) by its pious inscription; the Fort was built three centuries ago by a Mohammedan Emperor--a resanctification of the place in the interest of that religion </s>
<s> There is a Hindoo temple, too, with subterranean ramifications stocked with shrines and idols; and now the Fort belongs to the English, it contains a Christian Church </s>
<s> Insured in all the companies </s>
<s> From the lofty ramparts one has a fine view of the sacred rivers </s>
<s> They join at that point--the pale blue Jumna, apparently clean and clear, and the muddy Ganges, dull yellow and not clean </s>
<s> On a long curved spit between the rivers, towns of tents were visible, with a multitude of fluttering pennons, and a mighty swarm of pilgrims </s>
<s> It was a troublesome place to get down to, and not a quiet place when you arrived; but it was interesting </s>
<s> There was a world of activity and turmoil and noise, partly religious, partly commercial; for the Mohammedans were there to curse and sell, and the Hindoos to buy and pray </s>
<s> It is a fair as well as a religious festival </s>
<s> Crowds were bathing, praying, and drinking the purifying waters, and many sick pilgrims had come long journeys in palanquins to be healed of their maladies by a bath; or if that might not be, then to die on the blessed banks and so make sure of heaven </s>
<s> There were fakeers in plenty, with their bodies dusted over with ashes and their long hair caked together with cow-dung; for the cow is holy and so is the rest of it; so holy that the good Hindoo peasant frescoes the walls of his hut with this refuse, and also constructs ornamental figures out of it for the gracing of his dirt floor </s>
<s> There were seated families, fearfully and wonderfully painted, who by attitude and grouping represented the families of certain great gods </s>
<s> There was a holy man who sat naked by the day and by the week on a cluster of iron spikes, and did not seem to mind it; and another holy man, who stood all day holding his withered arms motionless aloft, and was said to have been doing it for years </s>
<s> All of these performers have a cloth on the ground beside them for the reception of contributions, and even the poorest of the people give a trifle and hope that the sacrifice will be blessed to him </s>
<s> At last came a procession of naked holy people marching by and chanting, and I wrenched myself away </s>

<s> The man who is ostentatious of his modesty is twin to the statue that wears a fig-leaf </s>
<s> --Pudd'nhead Wilson's New Calendar </s>
<s> The journey to Benares was all in daylight, and occupied but a few hours </s>
<s> It was admirably dusty </s>
<s> The dust settled upon you in a thick ashy layer and turned you into a fakeer, with nothing lacking to the role but the cow manure and the sense of holiness </s>
<s> There was a change of cars about mid-afternoon at Moghul-serai--if that was the name--and a wait of two hours there for the Benares train </s>
<s> We could have found a carriage and driven to the sacred city, but we should have lost the wait </s>
<s> In other countries a long wait at a station is a dull thing and tedious, but one has no right to have that feeling in India </s>
<s> You have the monster crowd of bejeweled natives, the stir, the bustle, the confusion, the shifting splendors of the costumes--dear me, the delight of it, the charm of it are beyond speech </s>
<s> The two-hour wait was over too soon </s>

<s> The general show came so near to exhausting variety that one would have said that no addition to it could be conspicuous, but when this Falstaff and his motleys marched through it one saw that that seeming impossibility had happened </s>

<s> A canvas-box is not much of a sight--when empty; but when there is a lady in it, it is an object of interest </s>
<s> These boxes were grouped apart, in the full blaze of the terrible sun during the three-quarters of an hour that we tarried there </s>
<s> They contained zenana ladies </s>
<s> They had to sit up; there was not room enough to stretch out </s>
<s> They probably did not mind it </s>
<s> They are used to the close captivity of their dwellings all their lives; when they go a journey they are carried to the train in these boxes; in the train they have to be secluded from inspection </s>
<s> Many people pity them, and I always did it myself and never charged anything; but it is doubtful if this compassion is valued </s>
<s> While we were in India some good-hearted Europeans in one of the cities proposed to restrict a large park to the use of zenana ladies, so that they could go there and in assured privacy go about unveiled and enjoy the sunshine and air as they had never enjoyed them before </s>
<s> The good intentions back of the proposition were recognized, and sincere thanks returned for it, but the proposition itself met with a prompt declination at the hands of those who were authorized to speak for the zenana ladies </s>
<s> Apparently, the idea was shocking to the ladies--indeed, it was quite manifestly shocking </s>
<s> Was that proposition the equivalent of inviting European ladies to assemble scantily and scandalously clothed in the seclusion of a private park </s>
<s> It seemed to be about that </s>
<s> Without doubt modesty is nothing less than a holy feeling; and without doubt the person whose rule of modesty has been transgressed feels the same sort of wound that he would feel if something made holy to him by his religion had suffered a desecration </s>
<s> I say "rule of modesty" because there are about a million rules in the world, and this makes a million standards to be looked out for </s>
<s> Major Sleeman mentions the case of some high-caste veiled ladies who were profoundly scandalized when some English young ladies passed by with faces bare to the world; so scandalized that they spoke out with strong indignation and wondered that people could be so shameless as to expose their persons like that </s>
<s> And yet "the legs of the objectors were naked to mid-thigh" </s>
<s> Both parties were clean-minded and irreproachably modest, while abiding by their separate rules, but they couldn't have traded rules for a change without suffering considerable discomfort </s>
<s> All human rules are more or less idiotic, I suppose </s>
<s> It is best so, no doubt </s>
<s> The way it is now, the asylums can hold the sane people, but if we tried to shut up the insane we should run out of building materials </s>
<s> You have a long drive through the outskirts of Benares before you get to the hotel </s>
<s> And all the aspects are melancholy </s>
<s> It is a vision of dusty sterility, decaying temples, crumbling tombs, broken mud walls, shabby huts </s>

<s> We were still outside of the great native city when we reached the hotel </s>

<s> But we liked its annex better, and went thither </s>
<s> It was a mile away, perhaps, and stood in the midst of a large compound, and was built bungalow fashion, everything on the ground floor, and a veranda all around </s>
<s> They have doors in India, but I don't know why </s>
<s> They don't fasten, and they stand open, as a rule, with a curtain hanging in the doorspace to keep out the glare of the sun </s>
<s> Still, there is plenty of privacy, for no white person will come in without notice, of course </s>
<s> The native men servants will, but they don't seem to count </s>
<s> They glide in, barefoot and noiseless, and are in the midst before one knows it </s>
<s> At first this is a shock, and sometimes it is an embarrassment; but one has to get used to it, and does </s>
<s> There was one tree in the compound, and a monkey lived in it </s>
<s> At first I was strongly interested in the tree, for I was told that it was the renowned peepul--the tree in whose shadow you cannot tell a lie </s>
<s> This one failed to stand the test, and I went away from it disappointed </s>
<s> There was a softly creaking well close by, and a couple of oxen drew water from it by the hour, superintended by two natives dressed in the usual "turban and pocket-handkerchief" </s>
<s> The tree and the well were the only scenery, and so the compound was a soothing and lonesome and satisfying place; and very restful after so many activities </s>
<s> There was nobody in our bungalow but ourselves; the other guests were in the next one, where the table d'hote was furnished </s>
<s> A body could not be more pleasantly situated </s>
<s> Each room had the customary bath attached--a room ten or twelve feet square, with a roomy stone-paved pit in it and abundance of water </s>
<s> One could not easily improve upon this arrangement, except by furnishing it with cold water and excluding the hot, in deference to the fervency of the climate; but that is forbidden </s>
<s> It would damage the bather's health </s>
<s> The stranger is warned against taking cold baths in India, but even the most intelligent strangers are fools, and they do not obey, and so they presently get laid up </s>
<s> I was the most intelligent fool that passed through, that year </s>
<s> But I am still more intelligent now </s>
<s> Now that it is too late </s>
<s> I wonder if the 'dorian', if that is the name of it, is another superstition, like the peepul tree </s>
<s> There was a great abundance and variety of tropical fruits, but the dorian was never in evidence </s>
<s> It was never the season for the dorian </s>
<s> It was always going to arrive from Burma sometime or other, but it never did </s>
<s> By all accounts it was a most strange fruit, and incomparably delicious to the taste, but not to the smell </s>
<s> Its rind was said to exude a stench of so atrocious a nature that when a dorian was in the room even the presence of a polecat was a refreshment </s>
<s> We found many who had eaten the dorian, and they all spoke of it with a sort of rapture </s>
<s> They said that if you could hold your nose until the fruit was in your mouth a sacred joy would suffuse you from head to foot that would make you oblivious to the smell of the rind, but that if your grip slipped and you caught the smell of the rind before the fruit was in your mouth, you would faint </s>
<s> There is a fortune in that rind </s>
<s> Some day somebody will import it into Europe and sell it for cheese </s>
<s> Benares was not a disappointment </s>
<s> It justified its reputation as a curiosity </s>
<s> It is on high ground, and overhangs a grand curve of the Ganges </s>
<s> It is a vast mass of building, compactly crusting a hill, and is cloven in all directions by an intricate confusion of cracks which stand for streets </s>
<s> Tall, slim minarets and beflagged temple-spires rise out of it and give it picturesqueness, viewed from the river </s>
<s> The city is as busy as an ant-hill, and the hurly-burly of human life swarming along the web of narrow streets reminds one of the ants </s>
<s> The sacred cow swarms along, too, and goes whither she pleases, and takes toll of the grain-shops, and is very much in the way, and is a good deal of a nuisance, since she must not be molested </s>
<s> Benares is older than history, older than tradition, older even than legend, and looks twice as old as all of them put together </s>
<s> From a Hindoo statement quoted in Rev </s>
<s> Mr Parker's compact and lucid Guide to Benares, I find that the site of the town was the beginning-place of the Creation </s>
<s> It was merely an upright "lingam," at first, no larger than a stove-pipe, and stood in the midst of a shoreless ocean </s>
<s> This was the work of the God Vishnu </s>
<s> Later he spread the lingam out till its surface was ten miles across </s>
<s> Still it was not large enough for the business; therefore he presently built the globe around it </s>
<s> Benares is thus the center of the earth </s>
<s> This is considered an advantage </s>
<s> It has had a tumultuous history, both materially and spiritually </s>
<s> It started Brahminically, many ages ago; then by and by Buddha came in recent times 2,500 years ago, and after that it was Buddhist during many centuries--twelve, perhaps--but the Brahmins got the upper hand again, then, and have held it ever since </s>
<s> It is unspeakably sacred in Hindoo eyes, and is as unsanitary as it is sacred, and smells like the rind of the dorian </s>
<s> It is the headquarters of the Brahmin faith, and one-eighth of the population are priests of that church </s>
<s> But it is not an overstock, for they have all India as a prey </s>
<s> All India flocks thither on pilgrimage, and pours its savings into the pockets of the priests in a generous stream, which never fails </s>
<s> A priest with a good stand on the shore of the Ganges is much better off than the sweeper of the best crossing in London </s>
<s> A good stand is worth a world of money </s>
<s> The holy proprietor of it sits under his grand spectacular umbrella and blesses people all his life, and collects his commission, and grows fat and rich; and the stand passes from father to son, down and down and down through the ages, and remains a permanent and lucrative estate in the family </s>
<s> As Mr Parker suggests, it can become a subject of dispute, at one time or another, and then the matter will be settled, not by prayer and fasting and consultations with Vishnu, but by the intervention of a much more puissant power--an English court </s>
<s> In Bombay I was told by an American missionary that in India there are 640 Protestant missionaries at work </s>
<s> At first it seemed an immense force, but of course that was a thoughtless idea </s>
<s> One missionary to 500,000 natives--no, that is not a force; it is the reverse of it; 640 marching against an intrenched camp of 300,000,000--the odds are too great </s>
<s> A force of 640 in Benares alone would have its hands over-full with 8,000 Brahmin priests for adversary </s>
<s> Missionaries need to be well equipped with hope and confidence, and this equipment they seem to have always had in all parts of the world </s>
<s> Mr Parker has it </s>
<s> It enables him to get a favorable outlook out of statistics which might add up differently with other mathematicians </s>
<s> For instance: "During the past few years competent observers declare that the number of pilgrims to Benares has increased" </s>
<s> And then he adds up this fact and gets this conclusion: "But the revival, if so it may be called, has in it the marks of death </s>
<s> It is a spasmodic struggle before dissolution" </s>
<s> In this world we have seen the Roman Catholic power dying, upon these same terms, for many centuries </s>
<s> Many a time we have gotten all ready for the funeral and found it postponed again, on account of the weather or something </s>
<s> Taught by experience, we ought not to put on our things for this Brahminical one till we see the procession move </s>
<s> Apparently one of the most uncertain things in the world is the funeral of a religion </s>
<s> I should have been glad to acquire some sort of idea of Hindoo theology, but the difficulties were too great, the matter was too intricate </s>
<s> Even the mere A, B, C of it is baffling </s>
<s> There is a trinity--Brahma, Shiva, and Vishnu--independent powers, apparently, though one cannot feel quite sure of that, because in one of the temples there is an image where an attempt has been made to concentrate the three in one person </s>
<s> The three have other names and plenty of them, and this makes confusion in one's mind </s>
<s> The three have wives and the wives have several names, and this increases the confusion </s>
<s> There are children, the children have many names, and thus the confusion goes on and on </s>
<s> It is not worth while to try to get any grip upon the cloud of minor gods, there are too many of them </s>
<s> It is even a justifiable economy to leave Brahma, the chiefest god of all, out of your studies, for he seems to cut no great figure in India </s>
<s> The vast bulk of the national worship is lavished upon Shiva and Vishnu and their families </s>
<s> Shiva's symbol--the "lingam" with which Vishnu began the Creation--is worshiped by everybody, apparently </s>
<s> It is the commonest object in Benares </s>
<s> It is on view everywhere, it is garlanded with flowers, offerings are made to it, it suffers no neglect </s>
<s> Commonly it is an upright stone, shaped like a thimble--sometimes like an elongated thimble </s>
<s> This priapus-worship, then, is older than history </s>
<s> Mr Parker says that the lingams in Benares "outnumber the inhabitants" </s>
<s> In Benares there are many Mohammedan mosques </s>
<s> There are Hindoo temples without number--these quaintly shaped and elaborately sculptured little stone jugs crowd all the lanes </s>
<s> The Ganges itself and every individual drop of water in it are temples </s>
<s> Religion, then, is the business of Benares, just as gold-production is the business of Johannesburg </s>
<s> Other industries count for nothing as compared with the vast and all-absorbing rush and drive and boom of the town's specialty </s>
<s> Benares is the sacredest of sacred cities </s>
<s> The moment you step across the sharply-defined line which separates it from the rest of the globe, you stand upon ineffably and unspeakably holy ground </s>
<s> Mr Parker says: "It is impossible to convey any adequate idea of the intense feelings of veneration and affection with which the pious Hindoo regards 'Holy Kashi' (Benares)" </s>
<s> And then he gives you this vivid and moving picture: "Let a Hindoo regiment be marched through the district, and as soon as they cross the line and enter the limits of the holy place they rend the air with cries of 'Kashi ji ki jai--jai </s>
<s> (Holy Kashi </s>
<s> Hail to thee </s>
<s> Hail </s>
<s> Hail </s>
<s> Hail)' </s>
<s> The weary pilgrim scarcely able to stand, with age and weakness, blinded by the dust and heat, and almost dead with fatigue, crawls out of the oven-like railway carriage and as soon as his feet touch the ground he lifts up his withered hands and utters the same pious exclamation </s>
<s> Let a European in some distant city in casual talk in the bazar mention the fact that he has lived at Benares, and at once voices will be raised to call down blessings on his head, for a dweller in Benares is of all men most blessed" </s>
<s> It makes our own religious enthusiasm seem pale and cold </s>
<s> Inasmuch as the life of religion is in the heart, not the head, Mr Parker's touching picture seems to promise a sort of indefinite postponement of that funeral </s>
<s> CHAPTER LI </s>
<s> Let me make the superstitions of a nation and I care not who makes its laws or its songs either </s>
<s> --Pudd'nhead Wilson's New Calendar </s>
<s> Yes, the city of Benares is in effect just a big church, a religious hive, whose every cell is a temple, a shrine or a mosque, and whose every conceivable earthly and heavenly good is procurable under one roof, so to speak--a sort of Army and Navy Stores, theologically stocked </s>
<s> I will make out a little itinerary for the pilgrim; then you will see how handy the system is, how convenient, how comprehensive </s>
<s> If you go to Benares with a serious desire to spiritually benefit yourself, you will find it valuable </s>
<s> I got some of the facts from conversations with the Rev </s>
<s> Mr Parker and the others from his Guide to Benares; they are therefore trustworthy </s>
<s> 1 </s>
<s> Purification </s>
<s> At sunrise you must go down to the Ganges and bathe, pray, and drink some of the water </s>
<s> This is for your general purification </s>
<s> 2 </s>
<s> Protection against Hunger </s>
<s> Next, you must fortify yourself against the sorrowful earthly ill just named </s>
<s> This you will do by worshiping for a moment in the Cow Temple </s>
<s> By the door of it you will find an image of Ganesh, son of Shiva; it has the head of an elephant on a human body; its face and hands are of silver </s>
<s> You will worship it a little, and pass on, into a covered veranda, where you will find devotees reciting from the sacred books, with the help of instructors </s>
<s> In this place are groups of rude and dismal idols </s>
<s> You may contribute something for their support; then pass into the temple, a grim and stenchy place, for it is populous with sacred cows and with beggars </s>
<s> You will give something to the beggars, and "reverently kiss the tails" of such cows as pass along, for these cows are peculiarly holy, and this act of worship will secure you from hunger for the day </s>
<s> 3 </s>
<s> "The Poor Man's Friend" </s>
<s> You will next worship this god </s>
<s> He is at the bottom of a stone cistern in the temple of Dalbhyeswar, under the shade of a noble peepul tree on the bluff overlooking the Ganges, so you must go back to the river </s>
<s> The Poor Man's Friend is the god of material prosperity in general, and the god of the rain in particular </s>
<s> You will secure material prosperity, or both, by worshiping him </s>
<s> He is Shiva, under a new alias, and he abides in the bottom of that cistern, in the form of a stone lingam </s>
<s> You pour Ganges water over him, and in return for this homage you get the promised benefits </s>
<s> If there is any delay about the rain, you must pour water in until the cistern is full; the rain will then be sure to come </s>
<s> 4 </s>
<s> Fever </s>
<s> At the Kedar Ghat you will find a long flight of stone steps leading down to the river </s>
<s> Half way down is a tank filled with sewage </s>
<s> Drink as much of it as you want </s>
<s> It is for fever </s>
<s> 5 </s>
<s> Smallpox </s>
<s> Go straight from there to the central Ghat </s>
<s> At its upstream end you will find a small whitewashed building, which is a temple sacred to Sitala, goddess of smallpox </s>
<s> Her under-study is there --a rude human figure behind a brass screen </s>
<s> You will worship this for reasons to be furnished presently </s>
<s> 6 </s>
<s> The Well of Fate </s>
<s> For certain reasons you will next go and do homage at this well </s>
<s> You will find it in the Dandpan Temple, in the city </s>
<s> The sunlight falls into it from a square hole in the masonry above </s>
<s> You will approach it with awe, for your life is now at stake </s>
<s> You will bend over and look </s>
<s> If the fates are propitious, you will see your face pictured in the water far down in the well </s>
<s> If matters have been otherwise ordered, a sudden cloud will mask the sun and you will see nothing </s>
<s> This means that you have not six months to live </s>
<s> If you are already at the point of death, your circumstances are now serious </s>
<s> There is no time to lose </s>
<s> Let this world go, arrange for the next one </s>
<s> Handily situated, at your very elbow, is opportunity for this </s>
<s> You turn and worship the image of Maha Kal, the Great Fate, and happiness in the life to come is secured </s>
<s> If there is breath in your body yet, you should now make an effort to get a further lease of the present life </s>
<s> You have a chance </s>
<s> There is a chance for everything in this admirably stocked and wonderfully systemized Spiritual and Temporal Army and Navy Store </s>
<s> You must get yourself carried to the 7 </s>
<s> Well of Long Life </s>
<s> This is within the precincts of the mouldering and venerable Briddhkal Temple, which is one of the oldest in Benares </s>
<s> You pass in by a stone image of the monkey god, Hanuman, and there, among the ruined courtyards, you will find a shallow pool of stagnant sewage </s>
<s> It smells like the best limburger cheese, and is filthy with the washings of rotting lepers, but that is nothing, bathe in it; bathe in it gratefully and worshipfully, for this is the Fountain of Youth; these are the Waters of Long Life </s>
<s> Your gray hairs will disappear, and with them your wrinkles and your rheumatism, the burdens of care and the weariness of age, and you will come out young, fresh, elastic, and full of eagerness for the new race of life </s>
<s> Now will come flooding upon you the manifold desires that haunt the dear dreams of the morning of life </s>
<s> You will go whither you will find 8 </s>
<s> Fulfillment of Desire </s>
<s> To wit, to the Kameshwar Temple, sacred to Shiva as the Lord of Desires </s>
<s> Arrange for yours there </s>
<s> And if you like to look at idols among the pack and jam of temples, there you will find enough to stock a museum </s>
<s> You will begin to commit sins now with a fresh, new vivacity; therefore, it will be well to go frequently to a place where you can get 9 </s>
<s> Temporary Cleansing from Sin </s>
<s> To wit, to the Well of the Earring </s>
<s> You must approach this with the profoundest reverence, for it is unutterably sacred </s>
<s> It is, indeed, the most sacred place in Benares, the very Holy of Holies, in the estimation of the people </s>
<s> It is a railed tank, with stone stairways leading down to the water </s>
<s> The water is not clean </s>
<s> Of course it could not be, for people are always bathing in it </s>
<s> As long as you choose to stand and look, you will see the files of sinners descending and ascending--descending soiled with sin, ascending purged from it </s>
<s> "The liar, the thief, the murderer, and the adulterer may here wash and be clean," says the Rev </s>
<s> Mr Parker, in his book </s>
<s> Very well </s>
<s> I know Mr Parker, and I believe it; but if anybody else had said it, I should consider him a person who had better go down in the tank and take another wash </s>
<s> The god Vishnu dug this tank </s>
<s> He had nothing to dig with but his "discus" </s>
<s> I do not know what a discus is, but I know it is a poor thing to dig tanks with, because, by the time this one was finished, it was full of sweat--Vishnu's sweat </s>
<s> He constructed the site that Benares stands on, and afterward built the globe around it, and thought nothing of it, yet sweated like that over a little thing like this tank </s>
<s> One of these statements is doubtful </s>
<s> I do not know which one it is, but I think it difficult not to believe that a god who could build a world around Benares would not be intelligent enough to build it around the tank too, and not have to dig it </s>
<s> Youth, long life, temporary purification from sin, salvation through propitiation of the Great Fate --these are all good </s>
<s> But you must do something more </s>
<s> You must 10 </s>
<s> Make Salvation Sure </s>
<s> There are several ways </s>
<s> To get drowned in the Ganges is one, but that is not pleasant </s>
<s> To die within the limits of Benares is another; but that is a risky one, because you might be out of town when your time came </s>
<s> The best one of all is the Pilgrimage Around the City </s>
<s> You must walk; also, you must go barefoot </s>
<s> The tramp is forty-four miles, for the road winds out into the country a piece, and you will be marching five or six days </s>
<s> But you will have plenty of company </s>
<s> You will move with throngs and hosts of happy pilgrims whose radiant costumes will make the spectacle beautiful and whose glad songs and holy pans of triumph will banish your fatigues and cheer your spirit; and at intervals there will be temples where you may sleep and be refreshed with food </s>
<s> The pilgrimage completed, you have purchased salvation, and paid for it </s>
<s> But you may not get it unless you 11 </s>
<s> Get Your Redemption Recorded </s>
<s> You can get this done at the Sakhi Binayak Temple, and it is best to do it, for otherwise you might not be able to prove that you had made the pilgrimage in case the matter should some day come to be disputed </s>
<s> That temple is in a lane back of the Cow Temple </s>
<s> Over the door is a red image of Ganesh of the elephant head, son and heir of Shiva, and Prince of Wales to the Theological Monarchy, so to speak </s>
<s> Within is a god whose office it is to record your pilgrimage and be responsible for you </s>
<s> You will not see him, but you will see a Brahmin who will attend to the matter and take the money </s>
<s> If he should forget to collect the money, you can remind him </s>
<s> HE knows that your salvation is now secure, but of course you would like to know it yourself </s>
<s> You have nothing to do but go and pray, and pay at the 12 </s>
<s> Well of the Knowledge of Salvation </s>
<s> It is close to the Golden Temple </s>
<s> There you will see, sculptured out of a single piece of black marble, a bull which is much larger than any living bull you have ever seen, and yet is not a good likeness after all </s>
<s> And there also you will see a very uncommon thing--an image of Shiva </s>
<s> You have seen his lingam fifty thousand times already, but this is Shiva himself, and said to be a good likeness </s>
<s> It has three eyes </s>
<s> He is the only god in the firm that has three </s>
<s> "The well is covered by a fine canopy of stone supported by forty pillars," and around it you will find what you have already seen at almost every shrine you have visited in Benares, a mob of devout and eager pilgrims </s>
<s> The sacred water is being ladled out to them; with it comes to them the knowledge, clear, thrilling, absolute, that they are saved; and you can see by their faces that there is one happiness in this world which is supreme, and to which no other joy is comparable </s>
<s> You receive your water, you make your deposit, and now what more would you have </s>
<s> Gold, diamonds, power, fame </s>
<s> All in a single moment these things have withered to dirt, dust, ashes </s>
<s> The world has nothing to give you now </s>
<s> For you it is bankrupt </s>
<s> I do not claim that the pilgrims do their acts of worship in the order and sequence above charted out in this Itinerary of mine, but I think logic suggests that they ought to do so </s>
<s> Instead of a helter-skelter worship, we then have a definite starting-place, and a march which carries the pilgrim steadily forward by reasoned and logical progression to a definite goal </s>
<s> Thus, his Ganges bath in the early morning gives him an appetite; he kisses the cow-tails, and that removes it </s>
<s> It is now business hours, and longings for material prosperity rise in his mind, and he goes and pours water over Shiva's symbol; this insures the prosperity, but also brings on a rain, which gives him a fever </s>
<s> Then he drinks the sewage at the Kedar Ghat to cure the fever; it cures the fever but gives him the smallpox </s>
<s> He wishes to know how it is going to turn out; he goes to the Dandpan Temple and looks down the well </s>
<s> A clouded sun shows him that death is near </s>
<s> Logically his best course for the present, since he cannot tell at what moment he may die, is to secure a happy hereafter; this he does, through the agency of the Great Fate </s>
<s> He is safe, now, for heaven; his next move will naturally be to keep out of it as long as he can </s>
<s> Therefore he goes to the Briddhkal Temple and secures Youth and long life by bathing in a puddle of leper-pus which would kill a microbe </s>
<s> Logically, Youth has re-equipped him for sin and with the disposition to commit it; he will naturally go to the fane which is consecrated to the Fulfillment of Desires, and make arrangements </s>
<s> Logically, he will now go to the Well of the Earring from time to time to unload and freshen up for further banned enjoyments </s>
<s> But first and last and all the time he is human, and therefore in his reflective intervals he will always be speculating in "futures" </s>
<s> He will make the Great Pilgrimage around the city and so make his salvation absolutely sure; he will also have record made of it, so that it may remain absolutely sure and not be forgotten or repudiated in the confusion of the Final Settlement </s>
<s> Logically, also, he will wish to have satisfying and tranquilizing personal knowledge that that salvation is secure; therefore he goes to the Well of the Knowledge of Salvation, adds that completing detail, and then goes about his affairs serene and content; serene and content, for he is now royally endowed with an advantage which no religion in this world could give him but his own; for henceforth he may commit as many million sins as he wants to and nothing can come of it </s>
<s> Thus the system, properly and logically ordered, is neat, compact, clearly defined, and covers the whole ground </s>
<s> I desire to recommend it to such as find the other systems too difficult, exacting, and irksome for the uses of this fretful brief life of ours </s>
<s> However, let me not deceive any one </s>
<s> My Itinerary lacks a detail </s>
<s> I must put it in </s>
<s> The truth is, that after the pilgrim has faithfully followed the requirements of the Itinerary through to the end and has secured his salvation and also the personal knowledge of that fact, there is still an accident possible to him which can annul the whole thing </s>
<s> If he should ever cross to the other side of the Ganges and get caught out and die there he would at once come to life again in the form of an ass </s>
<s> Think of that, after all this trouble and expense </s>
<s> You see how capricious and uncertain salvation is there </s>
<s> The Hindoo has a childish and unreasoning aversion to being turned into an ass </s>
<s> It is hard to tell why </s>
<s> One could properly expect an ass to have an aversion to being turned into a Hindoo </s>
<s> One could understand that he could lose dignity by it; also self-respect, and nine-tenths of his intelligence </s>
<s> But the Hindoo changed into an ass wouldn't lose anything, unless you count his religion </s>
<s> And he would gain much--release from his slavery to two million gods and twenty million priests, fakeers, holy mendicants, and other sacred bacilli; he would escape the Hindoo hell; he would also escape the Hindoo heaven </s>
<s> These are advantages which the Hindoo ought to consider; then he would go over and die on the other side </s>
<s> Benares is a religious Vesuvius </s>
<s> In its bowels the theological forces have been heaving and tossing, rumbling, thundering and quaking, boiling, and weltering and flaming and smoking for ages </s>
<s> But a little group of missionaries have taken post at its base, and they have hopes </s>
<s> There are the Baptist Missionary Society, the Church Missionary Society, the London Missionary Society, the Wesleyan Missionary Society, and the Zenana Bible and Medical Mission </s>
<s> They have schools, and the principal work seems to be among the children </s>
<s> And no doubt that part of the work prospers best, for grown people everywhere are always likely to cling to the religion they were brought up in </s>
<s> CHAPTER LII </s>
<s> Wrinkles should merely indicate where smiles have been </s>
<s> --Pudd'nhead Wilson's New Calendar </s>
<s> In one of those Benares temples we saw a devotee working for salvation in a curious way </s>
<s> He had a huge wad of clay beside him and was making it up into little wee gods no bigger than carpet tacks </s>
<s> He stuck a grain of rice into each--to represent the lingam, I think </s>
<s> He turned them out nimbly, for he had had long practice and had acquired great facility </s>
<s> Every day he made 2,000 gods, then threw them into the holy Ganges </s>
<s> This act of homage brought him the profound homage of the pious--also their coppers </s>
<s> He had a sure living here, and was earning a high place in the hereafter </s>
<s> The Ganges front is the supreme show-place of Benares </s>
<s> Its tall bluffs are solidly caked from water to summit, along a stretch of three miles, with a splendid jumble of massive and picturesque masonry, a bewildering and beautiful confusion of stone platforms, temples, stair-flights, rich and stately palaces--nowhere a break, nowhere a glimpse of the bluff itself; all the long face of it is compactly walled from sight by this crammed perspective of platforms, soaring stairways, sculptured temples, majestic palaces, softening away into the distances; and there is movement, motion, human life everywhere, and brilliantly costumed --streaming in rainbows up and down the lofty stairways, and massed in metaphorical flower-gardens on the miles of great platforms at the river's edge </s>
<s> All this masonry, all this architecture represents piety </s>
<s> The palaces were built by native princes whose homes, as a rule, are far from Benares, but who go there from time to time to refresh their souls with the sight and touch of the Ganges, the river of their idolatry </s>
<s> The stairways are records of acts of piety; the crowd of costly little temples are tokens of money spent by rich men for present credit and hope of future reward </s>
<s> Apparently, the rich Christian who spends large sums upon his religion is conspicuous with us, by his rarity, but the rich Hindoo who doesn't spend large sums upon his religion is seemingly non-existent </s>
<s> With us the poor spend money on their religion, but they keep back some to live on </s>
<s> Apparently, in India, the poor bankrupt themselves daily for their religion </s>
<s> The rich Hindoo can afford his pious outlays; he gets much glory for his spendings, yet keeps back a sufficiency of his income for temporal purposes; but the poor Hindoo is entitled to compassion, for his spendings keep him poor, yet get him no glory </s>
<s> We made the usual trip up and down the river, seated in chairs under an awning on the deck of the usual commodious hand-propelled ark; made it two or three times, and could have made it with increasing interest and enjoyment many times more; for, of course, the palaces and temples would grow more and more beautiful every time one saw them, for that happens with all such things; also, I think one would not get tired of the bathers, nor their costumes, nor of their ingenuities in getting out of them and into them again without exposing too much bronze, nor of their devotional gesticulations and absorbed bead-tellings </s>

<s> Those people were not drinking that fearful stuff to assuage thirst, but in order to purify their souls and the interior of their bodies </s>

<s> A word further concerning the nasty but all-purifying Ganges water </s>
<s> When we went to Agra, by and by, we happened there just in time to be in at the birth of a marvel--a memorable scientific discovery--the discovery that in certain ways the foul and derided Ganges water is the most puissant purifier in the world </s>
<s> This curious fact, as I have said, had just been added to the treasury of modern science </s>
<s> It had long been noted as a strange thing that while Benares is often afflicted with the cholera she does not spread it beyond her borders </s>

<s> He got water at the mouths of the sewers where they empty into the river at the bathing ghats; a cubic centimetre of it contained millions of germs; at the end of six hours they were all dead </s>
<s> He caught a floating corpse, towed it to the shore, and from beside it he dipped up water that was swarming with cholera germs; at the end of six hours they were all dead </s>
<s> He added swarm after swarm of cholera germs to this water; within the six hours they always died, to the last sample </s>
<s> Repeatedly, he took pure well water which was barren of animal life, and put into it a few cholera germs; they always began to propagate at once, and always within six hours they swarmed--and were numberable by millions upon millions </s>

<s> A prominent episode in the Indian career of Warren Hastings had Benares for its theater </s>

<s> CHAPTER LIII </s>
<s> True irreverence is disrespect for another man's god </s>

<s> It was in Benares that I saw another living god </s>

<s> I believe I have seen most of the greater and lesser wonders of the world, but I do not remember that any of them interested me so overwhelmingly as did that pair of gods </s>
<s> When I try to account for this effect I find no difficulty about it </s>

<s> We get almost all our wonders at second hand </s>
<s> We are eager to see any celebrated thing--and we never fail of our reward; just the deep privilege of gazing upon an object which has stirred the enthusiasm or evoked the reverence or affection or admiration of multitudes of our race is a thing which we value; we are profoundly glad that we have seen it, we are permanently enriched from having seen it, we would not part with the memory of that experience for a great price </s>
<s> And yet that very spectacle may be the Taj </s>
<s> You cannot keep your enthusiasms down, you cannot keep your emotions within bounds when that soaring bubble of marble breaks upon your view </s>
<s> But these are not your enthusiasms and emotions--they are the accumulated emotions and enthusiasms of a thousand fervid writers, who have been slowly and steadily storing them up in your heart day by day and year by year all your life; and now they burst out in a flood and overwhelm you; and you could not be a whit happier if they were your very own </s>

<s> B </s>
<s> Saraswati has attained to what among the Hindoos is called the "state of perfection" </s>
<s> It is a state which other Hindoos reach by being born again and again, and over and over again into this world, through one re-incarnation after another--a tiresome long job covering centuries and decades of centuries, and one that is full of risks, too, like the accident of dying on the wrong side of the Ganges some time or other and waking up in the form of an ass, with a fresh start necessary and the numerous trips to be made all over again </s>
<s> But in reaching perfection, Sri 108 S </s>
<s> B </s>
<s> S </s>
<s> has escaped all that </s>
<s> He is no longer a part or a feature of this world; his substance has changed, all earthiness has departed out of it; he is utterly holy, utterly pure; nothing can desecrate this holiness or stain this purity; he is no longer of the earth, its concerns are matters foreign to him, its pains and griefs and troubles cannot reach him </s>
<s> When he dies, Nirvana is his; he will be absorbed into the substance of the Supreme Deity and be at peace forever </s>
<s> The Hindoo Scriptures point out how this state is to be reached, but it is only once in a thousand years, perhaps, that candidate accomplishes it </s>
<s> This one has traversed the course required, stage by stage, from the beginning to the end, and now has nothing left to do but wait for the call which shall release him from a world in which he has now no part nor lot </s>
<s> First, he passed through the student stage, and became learned in the holy books </s>

<s> It is a strange world </s>

<s> This pupil, Mina Bahadur Rana, is not a commonplace person, but a man of distinguished capacities and attainments, and, apparently, he had a fine worldly career in front of him </s>
<s> He was serving the Nepal Government in a high capacity at the Court of the Viceroy of India, twenty years ago </s>
<s> He was an able man, educated, a thinker, a man of property </s>
<s> But the longing to devote himself to a religious life came upon him, and he resigned his place, turned his back upon the vanities and comforts of the world, and went away into the solitudes to live in a hut and study the sacred writings and meditate upon virtue and holiness and seek to attain them </s>
<s> This sort of religion resembles ours </s>
<s> Christ recommended the rich to give away all their property and follow Him in poverty, not in worldly comfort </s>
<s> American and English millionaires do it every day, and thus verify and confirm to the world the tremendous forces that lie in religion </s>
<s> Yet many people scoff at them for this loyalty to duty, and many will scoff at Mina Bahadur Rana and call him a crank </s>
<s> Like many Christians of great character and intellect, he has made the study of his Scriptures and the writing of books of commentaries upon them the loving labor of his life </s>
<s> Like them, he has believed that his was not an idle and foolish waste of his life, but a most worthy and honorable employment of it </s>
<s> Yet, there are many people who will see in those others, men worthy of homage and deep reverence, but in him merely a crank </s>
<s> But I shall not </s>
<s> He has my reverence </s>
<s> And I don't offer it as a common thing and poor, but as an unusual thing and of value </s>
<s> The ordinary reverence, the reverence defined and explained by the dictionary costs nothing </s>
<s> Reverence for one's own sacred things--parents, religion, flag, laws, and respect for one's own beliefs--these are feelings which we cannot even help </s>
<s> They come natural to us; they are involuntary, like breathing </s>
<s> There is no personal merit in breathing </s>
<s> But the reverence which is difficult, and which has personal merit in it, is the respect which you pay, without compulsion, to the political or religious attitude of a man whose beliefs are not yours </s>
<s> You can't revere his gods or his politics, and no one expects you to do that, but you could respect his belief in them if you tried hard enough; and you could respect him, too, if you tried hard enough </s>
<s> But it is very, very difficult; it is next to impossible, and so we hardly ever try </s>
<s> If the man doesn't believe as we do, we say he is a crank, and that settles it </s>
<s> I mean it does nowadays, because now we can't burn him </s>
<s> We are always canting about people's "irreverence," always charging this offense upon somebody or other, and thereby intimating that we are better than that person and do not commit that offense ourselves </s>
<s> Whenever we do this we are in a lying attitude, and our speech is cant; for none of us are reverent--in a meritorious way; deep down in our hearts we are all irreverent </s>
<s> There is probably not a single exception to this rule in the earth </s>
<s> There is probably not one person whose reverence rises higher than respect for his own sacred things; and therefore, it is not a thing to boast about and be proud of, since the most degraded savage has that --and, like the best of us, has nothing higher </s>
<s> To speak plainly, we despise all reverences and all objects of reverence which are outside the pale of our own list of sacred things </s>
<s> And yet, with strange inconsistency, we are shocked when other people despise and defile the things which are holy to us </s>
<s> Suppose we should meet with a paragraph like the following, in the newspapers: "Yesterday a visiting party of the British nobility had a picnic at Mount Vernon, and in the tomb of Washington they ate their luncheon, sang popular songs, played games, and danced waltzes and polkas" </s>
<s> Should we be shocked </s>
<s> Should we feel outraged </s>
<s> Should we be amazed </s>
<s> Should we call the performance a desecration </s>
<s> Yes, that would all happen </s>
<s> We should denounce those people in round terms, and call them hard names </s>
<s> And suppose we found this paragraph in the newspapers: "Yesterday a visiting party of American pork-millionaires had a picnic in Westminster Abbey, and in that sacred place they ate their luncheon, sang popular songs, played games, and danced waltzes and polkas" </s>
<s> Would the English be shocked </s>
<s> Would they feel outraged </s>
<s> Would they be amazed </s>
<s> Would they call the performance a desecration </s>
<s> That would all happen </s>
<s> The pork-millionaires would be denounced in round terms; they would be called hard names </s>
<s> In the tomb at Mount Vernon lie the ashes of America's most honored son; in the Abbey, the ashes of England's greatest dead; the tomb of tombs, the costliest in the earth, the wonder of the world, the Taj, was built by a great Emperor to honor the memory of a perfect wife and perfect mother, one in whom there was no spot or blemish, whose love was his stay and support, whose life was the light of the world to him; in it her ashes lie, and to the Mohammedan millions of India it is a holy place; to them it is what Mount Vernon is to Americans, it is what the Abbey is to the English </s>
<s> Major Sleeman wrote forty or fifty years ago (the italics are mine): "I would here enter my humble protest against the quadrille and lunch parties which are sometimes given to European ladies and gentlemen of the station at this imperial tomb; drinking and dancing are no doubt very good things in their season, but they are sadly out of place in a sepulchre" </s>
<s> Were there any Americans among those lunch parties </s>

<s> CHAPTER LIV </s>
<s> Do not undervalue the headache </s>
